timeline.bodyText: Maybe "supported_architectures" or "architecture_support_override" @nikosmoum what do you think?
timeline.author: barnabycourt

replies.bodyText: I agree that the word "package(s)" is not needed. All that candlepin needs to know is that a consumer/system can support multiple architectures, so "supported_architectures" sounds good (ideally a non-debian/ubuntu client could re-use the same fact for supporting multiple architectures that comes from something other than a file managed by a package management system).
replies.author: nikosmoum

replies.bodyText: Thank you very much for your suggestions. I updated the PR but was not able to test it right now.
replies.author: sbernhard

timeline.message:
Add supported_architecture fact

The 'supported_architectures' fact is used to provide the information which
architectures (like i386, amd64) a host supports. This is used e.g. on
Debian / Ubuntu hosts to support multiple architectures. A common scenario is to
use amd64 and i386 on Debian / Ubuntu. Therefore, the host needs to be able to install
packages from amd64 and i386 repositories.
